conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with child, sled, and force applied.
Drawing a free-body diagram to visualize forces.
Total mass of system is 40 kg.
Weight of the system is 400 N downward.
Normal force from ground acts upward.
Force F applied at 37 degrees above horizontal.
Net force in horizontal direction is zero due to constant speed.
Net force in vertical direction is zero as system isn't accelerating vertically.
Resolve force F into horizontal component: 80 N.
Resolve force F into vertical component: 60 N.
Sum of vertical forces: N + 60 - 400 = 0, so N = 340 N.
Direction of vertical component of F is upward.
Normal force is 340 N upward.
Pressure is normal force divided by area.
Without area, can't calculate actual pressure.
Considering horizontal forces: frictional force f and horizontal component of F.
Frictional force f = 80 N due to constant speed.
Frictional force related to normal force by f = Î¼ * N.
Pressure might be used interchangeably with force in this context.
Clarifying what is being asked by the question.
Question might be asking for normal force or assuming unit area.
Considering other forces due to sled being pulled.
Re-evaluating forces: weight 400 N down, normal force N up, vertical component of F 60 N up.
